Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: Their timely presence is crucial at a high-stakes proceeding that could determine the case outcome
Story: My phone buzzed with a reminder: the court session was in forty minutes. I glanced at my brother, helmet askew, grinning as he eyed the steep, cracked ramp in our driveway. “Watch this, I’ve almost got it,” he said, clutching his skateboard. As his sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t do anything reckless. But as an advocate, I had to be at the courthouse on time—today’s hearing could make or break my client’s future. My brother’s last fall had left him limping for days, and the thought of him trying this trick alone made my stomach twist. Yet, if I left now, I’d barely make it to court. I could hear my client’s anxious voice in my head, counting on me to show up, to fight for them. My brother’s hopeful eyes met mine, waiting for my encouragement or warning. I stood frozen, torn between the ramp and the courthouse, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which responsibility I could bear to let down.
